subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: A little story in Romanized QS
msgSnippet: ... I used them in the little story. ... Quite right, of course. ... Almost certainly more.  We expect the maximal diversity in the place where a language or
messageBody:
Moira O'Brien scripsit:

> It seems to be being ignored that the 8 basic abbreviations are intended to
> be used with Junior QS - see QM p12.

I used them in the little story.

> Another point, people are referring to British English. a) British is a
> nationality not a country and b) there is no such thing as British English -

Quite right, of course.

> In other words, there are as many varieties of English spoken in the British
> Isles as there are in the US and other English speaking nations.

Almost certainly more. We expect the maximal diversity in the place
where a language or family of languages originates. There is far more
diversity in England than in the other parts of the British Isles,
for example, which in turn have far more diversity than the ex-colonies.

Here's a more extreme example. Austronesian is one of the major families
of languages: it includes about 1200 different related languages (about
20% of the surviving spoken languages in the world). Austronesian
languages are spoken mostly on islands in the Pacific Ocean, as far
west as Sumatra, as far north as Hawaii, as far south as New Zealand,
and as far east as Easter Island. The family also includes Malay,
spoken on the Malay Peninsula of Asia, and Malagasy, spoken on the
island of Madagascar far away, just off the eastern coast of Africa.
The total number of speakers is at least 300 million, probably much more.

Linguists have divided the Austronesian family into ten major subfamilies,
analogous to the Germanic, Romance, Slavic, Iranian, Indic, and other
subfamilies of the Indo-European family (which is spoken from Ireland
to Central India). *Nine* of these families are spoken only by the few
remaining non-Chinese aboriginals on Taiwan: four living languages, six
dead ones, perhaps 250,000 speakers. The tenth family, Malayo-Polynesian,
accounts for all the rest. We can conclude, then, that the Austronesian
languages originated on Taiwan.

--
We call nothing profound cowan@...
that is not wittily expressed. John Cowan
--Northrop Frye (improved)
